data: Very Long Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase (VLCAD) Deficiency is a fatty acid oxidation disorder. Fatty acid oxidation is crucial in meeting energy requirements in periods of stress, fasting, infection and fever.    During illness patients may develop severe deterioration of general condition (lethargy, coma), vomiting, hypoketotic hypoglycemia, cardiac arrhythmia, cardiomyopathy, hepatopathy, myopathy with exercise intolerance, myalgia and rhabdomyolysis, coma and/or cardiorespiratory arrest as a result of altered metabolism.    LABORATORY FINDINGS: Hypoglycemia without ketone bodies in urine, metabolic acidosis, high liver transaminases, creatine kinase and lactate dehdrogenase, hyperammonemia, elevated lactate, and myoglobunuria
q4h, starting 20 min after D10W bolus end and PRN
Patient may have sick day formula provided by caregiver as per patient care letter orally or via enteral tubes
Provide patient with high glucose containing oral solution (apple juice) orally or via enteral tubes

2 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over: 30 minute, drug form: bag
2 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over: 10 minute, drug form: bag
2 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over: 20 minute, drug form: bag
Consider sodium chloride 0.9% (NS) bolus based on clinical assessment for dehydration
PED ED Peripheral IV and IV Fluids (Module)

Start IV dextrose 10%-sodium chloride 0.9% (D10NS) at 1.5 times maintenance and reassess rate after 2 hours if:  - hypoglycemia, glucose less than 3.5 mmol/L  - in normoglycemia but not able to tolerate oral intake  - patient has diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, high fever, signs of encephalopathy  - ketones are high  - there is metabolic acidosis
Do not administer IV lipids, proPOFol or acetylsalicylic acid
If patient is on levOCARNitine supplements: Continue SAME oral dose if tolerated, otherwise give SAME DOSE as IV
levOCARNitine 100 to 400 mg/kg/day divided TID PO or NG
